description: ISS022-E-066963 (17 Feb. 2010) — This image is among the first taken through the Cupola’s unique seven-windowed bay window on the ISS. The coast of Algeria is visible, recorded with a digital camera and 28mm lens. The Cupola was delivered by STS-130 to house robotic arm controls and exterior observation.
A United States flag floats in front of Window 7 in the Cupola module. Image was released by astronaut on social media.
Overall view of the Cupola Module. Photo was taken during Expedition 38. Image released by astronaut on Twitter.
Earth observation taken through Cupola windows by the Expedition 39 crew. Portions of the ISS are in view.
High angle view showing the Cupola, backdropped by a solar array panel, on the ISS. (12 July 2011, faces of Atlantis STS-135 and Expedition 28 visible)
Cupola backdropped against the darkness of space and solar panels, with crew visible. (12 July 2011, STS-135 and Expedition 28)
Cupola against Earth's horizon and darkness of space, crew visible. (12 July 2011, STS-135 and Expedition 28)
A close-up view of the Cupola photographed by an Expedition 38 crew member (2 Feb 2014).
Cupola with shutters open, showing clouds over light blue background. Taken with 19mm lens, Feb 2010.
First image through the seven-windowed Cupola showing Sahara Desert through the windows. Location: Sudan near Al Fashir, taken with 12-24mm lens.
Expedition 60 crew capturing Hurricane Dorian from Cupola in Aug 2019.
NASA astronaut Scott Kelly, Expedition 26 commander, in the Cupola. Fish-eye lens attached.
Robotic workstation in Cupola, taken by Expedition 23 crew (fish-eye lens).
Cupola photo (Expedition 26, fish-eye lens).
Earth as seen through Cupola windows, Expedition 29, Nov 2011.
Aurora borealis from Cupola window, taken by Samantha Cristoforetti, Expedition 42.
Exterior view of Cupola Module with Koichi Wakata visible inside. Released on Twitter.
Earth and its horizon as seen through Cupola windows (Expedition 22, March 2010).
Canadarm2 seen from Cupola, with Earth as backdrop. Expedition 38.
Survey view of Cupola, Node 3, and PMA-3. Taken during Expedition 35.
Cupola photo, fish-eye lens, Expedition 26.
Cupola view photographed by STS-130 crew while docked.
Tranquility node and Cupola, photographed during Expedition 22 EVA.
Optical Nav investigation camera assembly in Cupola, ISS, Jan 2019.
Cupola robotics workstation by Expedition 36 (training for HTV-4 grapple/berthing), solar array and Earth's horizon visible.
Cupola robotics workstation, Expedition 36.
African continent as seen from Cupola (Terry Virts, 2015, tweeted photo).
Earth observation from ISS Cupola (Scott Kelly, tweeted #CapeTown #SouthAfrica #YearInSpace).
Expedition 39 Commander Koichi Wakata in Cupola (27 April 2014).
Portion of docked space shuttle Endeavour from Cupola. Earth’s horizon and blackness of space behind. (STS-134, May 2011)
ISS038-E-040615 (2 Feb. 2014) --- A close-up view of the Cupola is featured in this image photographed by an Expedition 38 crew member on the International Space Station.
S130-E-009694 (17 Feb. 2010) --- This image is among the initial series taken through the seven-windowed Cupola. Small clouds over a light blue background. Taken with a digital camera and 19mm lens.
ISS022-E-066972 (17 Feb. 2010) --- First image taken through Cupola's windows showing the Sahara Desert. Location: Sudan near Al Fashir. Taken with 12-24mm zoom lens.
ISS060E047724 (Aug. 30, 2019) — Expedition 60 crewmembers capture images of Hurricane Dorian from the cupola inside the ISS.
ISS026-E-005313 (26 Nov. 2010) --- Fish-eye lens image of NASA astronaut Scott Kelly, Expedition 26 commander, in the Cupola.
ISS023-E-039983 (8 May 2010) --- Robotic workstation in Cupola taken by Expedition 23 crew member using fish-eye lens.
ISS026-E-020937 (27 Jan. 2011) --- Cupola image taken by Expedition 26 member using fish-eye lens.
ISS029-E-043374 (19 Nov. 2011) --- Blue and white part of Earth, as seen through the windows in the Cupola, by Expedition 29.
ISS042E033478 (12/09/2014) --- Samantha Cristoforetti took this aurora borealis image from the cupola window. Expedition 42.
ISS039E017154 (27 April 2014) --- Exterior view of Cupola Module with Koichi Wakata visible inside. Released on Twitter.
ISS022-E-080014 (3 March 2010) --- Blue and white Earth's horizon through Cupola, by Expedition 22.
ISS038-E-015270 (12 Dec. 2013) --- Canadarm2 seen from Cupola, Earth as backdrop. Expedition 38.
ISS035E013954 (3 Apr. 2013) --- Survey view of Cupola, Node 3 & PMA-3, Expedition 35.
ISS026-E-020960 (27 Jan. 2011) --- Cupola photo, fish-eye lens, Expedition 26.
S130-E-010329 (18 Feb. 2010) --- Tranquility node’s Cupola, photo by STS-130 crew member.
ISS022-E-066919 (17 Feb. 2010) --- Tranquility node & Cupola by STS-130 spacewalker, EVA 3.
ISS058E007453 (1/29/2019) --- Camera assembly for Optical Navigation in Cupola aboard ISS.
ISS036E029203 (5 Aug. 2013) --- Cupola robotics workstation, solar array/Earth horizon. Training for HTV-4 grapple.
ISS036E029210 (5 Aug. 2013) --- Cupola robotics workstation, solar array/Earth horizon. Training for HTV-4.
ISS042E237302 (02/09/2015) --- Terry Virts captures African continent from Cupola window.
ISS043E198683 (05/16/2015) --- Scott Kelly's observation of Cape Town from Cupola. #YearInSpace
ISS039E017152 (27 April 2014) --- Koichi Wakata peers out Cupola; photo from Pirs docking module.
S134-E-008502 (23 May 2011) --- Portion of docked Endeavour photographed from Cupola.
ISS040E006193 (1 June 2014) --- Solar array wings and Cupola; Earth and space background.
ISS040E068619 (16 July 2014) --- ESA astronaut Alexander Gerst waves from Cupola; Canadarm2, Earth, stars.
ISS039E017171 (27 April 2014) --- Koichi Wakata peers out Cupola window; image by crewmate in Pirs.
ISS040E123163 (2 Sept. 2014) --- Solar arrays, Rassvet MRM1, and Cupola; Earth’s horizon background.
ISS040E006510 (1 June 2014) --- Kibo complex, ISS, solar arrays, Cupola sunsets; Earth’s atmosphere/space.
ISS022E068274 (18 Feb. 2010) --- Orbital sunrise by JAXA astronaut Soichi Noguchi from Cupola.
ISS040E123166 (2 Sept. 2014) --- Solar arrays, Rassvet MRM1, Cupola; photographed by Expedition 40.
ISS031E028009 (6 May 2012) --- ISS Cupola “upside down”; moon partially obscured by Japanese Experiment Module.
ISS043E021247 (17 Mar. 2015) --- Terry Virts, Commander of Expedition 43, double reflection in Cupola window at sunrise.
ISS038E015406 (12 Dec. 2013) --- Canadarm2 and end effector seen from Cupola by Expedition 38.

ISS022-E-066963 (17 Feb. 2010) --- This image is among the first taken through a first of its kind “bay window” on the International Space Station, the seven-windowed Cupola. The image shows the coast of Algeria featuring (in the Cupola’s round window) an area between the cities of Dellys and Algiers.
A United States flag floats in front of Window 7 in the Cupola module. Image was released by astronaut on social media.
Overall view of the Cupola Module. Photo was taken during Expedition 38. Image was released by astronaut on Twitter.
Earth observation taken through Cupola windows by the Expedition 39 crew. Portions of the ISS are in view.
ISS028-E-016246 (12 July 2011) — High angle view showing the Cupola, backdropped against a solar array panel on the ISS. Crew members can be seen in Cupola’s windows.
ISS028-E-016231 (12 July 2011) — Cupola backdropped against the darkness of space and solar panels, crew members visible.
ISS028-E-016227 (12 July 2011) — Cupola against space, Earth's horizon, crew in Cupola’s windows.
ISS038-E-040615 (2 Feb. 2014) — Close-up of Cupola, photographed by Expedition 38.
S130-E-009694 (17 Feb. 2010) — Initial images through the seven-windowed Cupola. Small clouds over blue background.
First image taken through Cupola windows showing the Sahara Desert, near Al Fashir.
Expedition 60 crew capturing Hurricane Dorian from Cupola in August 2019.
NASA astronaut Scott Kelly, Expedition 26 commander, captured in the Cupola with a fish-eye lens.
Robotic workstation in Cupola, taken by Expedition 23 with fish-eye lens.

ISS’s Tranquility node and Cupola, photographed by STS-130 spacewalker, EVA 3.

Earth observation from ISS Cupola (Scott Kelly, Cape Town, tweeted #YearInSpace).
Expedition 39 Commander Koichi Wakata photographed in Cupola.

Solar array wings, Cupola and Earth, photographed by Expedition 40.
ESA astronaut Alexander Gerst waves from Cupola; Canadarm2 and stars visible, Earth in background.
Koichi Wakata peers out of Cupola window, recorded by crewmate in Pirs (Expedition 39).

ISS Japanese Kibo complex, Cupola sunsets, and solar arrays. Earth's atmosphere and space.

Canadarm2 and its end effector seen from Cupola, Expedition 38.
